Insufficient information in abstract to determine whether it meets the social-task and healthy adult criteria—include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining person-selective responses in anterior temporal lobes and social cognition; uses task encoding facts about people (social processing). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract explicitly identifies the paper as a review rather than a primary fMRI study; it does not report original fMRI data on healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an imitation task related to social interaction and social cognition (urge to imitate). Fits social-related processing constructs; not a review and meets age/group criteria.

Study involves pediatric stroke patients and resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social-processing fMRI) and does not include a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the review criteria.

fMRI study examining Theory of Mind/social competition in healthy subjects using a social interaction task (human-human vs human-machine). Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related task during fMRI; healthy adult participants). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study measuring attractiveness comparisons—a form of perception/understanding of others (social processing) in human participants. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Original fMRI study using social cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) performed during scanning; includes a healthy matched control group (13 HCs). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages are not specified in abstract, participants are adults; study addresses social-related processing in healthy adults, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study reporting BOLD responses during tasks assessing animacy perception (a form of Perception and Understanding of Others/social perception) in human participants. Matches the review objective of social-related processing using fMRI. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not specify ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and other details.

fMRI study investigating neural processes of learning about others’ preferences (social cognition). It reports task-based fMRI during social-related processing. While participant health/age not specified in abstract, inclusion should proceed to full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI in awake dogs (non-human participants). The review objective requires functional MRI studies in healthy adult humans (ages 17–65). Because participants are animals, the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports neural responses to dynamic multimodal social/emotional stimuli in schizophrenia and depression, implying neuroimaging and likely inclusion of healthy controls; however it does not explicitly state fMRI nor participant ages. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm all inclusion criteria—include for full-text review.

The abstract describes ERP (EEG) research and theoretical review of emotion development and plasticity; it does not report fMRI scanning during a social-related task in healthy adults and appears to be a review/EEG-focused paper.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion, punishment and forgiveness during social tasks (Cyberball, modified Dictator Game) in human participants; meets social-related processing and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining biological motion perception (a social-perception task) and reports both schizophrenia and healthy participant groups, meeting the fMRI + healthy adult criteria. Age range not specified; include for full-text verification.

Functional MRI was used during a social task (Cyberball social exclusion), which assesses social processing. The sample compares genetic homozygotes with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders, implying healthy adults. Meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages.

The study used fMRI while participants performed a social attribution/Theory of Mind task (perception/understanding of others) and included a healthy control group of adult women. It is an original study (not a review). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study of interpersonal resource conflict involving human vs. computer partners, probing social processing (sharing, social appraisal). Not a review; meets the social-task and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants were infants (3–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review; thus the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

The study used fMRI to assess neural responses during a social exclusion task (social-related processing) in 21 healthy adult volunteers. It is an original experimental study (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used while participants read social vs non-social literary passages; the task probes social cognition and reports dmPFC activity mediating fiction-reading and social-cognition relation. Study involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review. Age range not stated, but abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Study includes a healthy adult group (ages 20-41) within the 17-65 range and used fMRI while participants performed a social-related task (discriminating social interactions from neutral movements). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI while participants made mental state judgments (social cognition), in a healthy adult sample (n=38). This directly fits the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract/title indicate event-related fMRI to positive social stimuli (social processing), but it does not specify whether a healthy adult comparison group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

Task uses fMRI to investigate recall of relationship episodes involving self and others (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others, affective/attachment dimensions). Sample: 35 healthy adults. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing including a healthy typically-developing control group, but participants described as 'youth' with no ages given. Age eligibility (17–65) unclear from abstract; include for full-text review to verify adult control ages.

fMRI study examining self-, mother-, and abstract-other (theory-of-mind) processing—these are social-related constructs (self/other understanding). Abstract implies healthy adult subjects and reports task-based BOLD activations. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (17–65) and health status.

fMRI study examining emotional inferences from vocalizations and music, implicating social cognition/social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state a healthy sample, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using the HCP social cognition paradigm (social processing). Includes a matched healthy control group (n=25), satisfying the requirement of at least one healthy adult group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Empirical fMRI study investigating neural responses to visually observed social interactions (interaction presence and type) in human participants. Uses task-based fMRI targeting social perception (pSTS/TPJ). Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract discusses functional neuroimaging of social cognition and mentions simultaneous fMRI of two individuals, but provides no details on participants, ages (17–65), or task specifics. It is not clearly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from abstract alone — include for full-text review to assess participant health, ages, and task details.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (n=17) where participants performed mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (reading stories and answering questions), which is social-related processing. No clinical groups are mentioned and participants appear to be healthy adults. The abstract lacks explicit age ranges, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant health.

fMRI was performed while healthy adult participants (n=15) observed and rated virtual social interactions—a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). The sample appears to be healthy adults and the paper is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

The fMRI task is a simple motor task examining cerebellar function in autism and controls; it does not involve social-related processing. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not meet the review objective of social processing.

fMRI study of mentalizing/social cognition (inferring others' preferences) in healthy adult participants (n=64). It reports task-based functional MRI related to self–other processing, matching inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-cognition components (attentional and attributional biases), which fits the review’s topic. The abstract does not specify whether healthy adult participants were included; insufficient information to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and ages.
fMRI study investigating voice recognition (a social communication/perception task) including matched healthy control participants (age 32), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

The article is a quantitative review/meta-analysis (ALE) of fMRI studies in clinical high-risk individuals, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not clearly report healthy adult social-task fMRI data.

Study used fMRI during a third-party punishment task (social processing: perception/understanding of others and moral responsibility). Participants are lay (healthy) adults; age range likely within 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study used fMRI during biological (body) motion perception, which maps onto social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports a group of healthy matched controls alongside a patient group, satisfying the healthy adult group criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Study used resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder (no healthy adult group aged 17–65) and did not involve participants completing a social-related task. Does not meet population or task-based fMRI inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The study therefore does not include the target adult healthy sample for the meta-analysis.
Participants are children (N=24, mean age 10.2 years), which falls outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and social processing task, the age criterion is not met.
Participants are adolescents (age 16–17). The review requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65 (adults). The sample does not meet the adult age criterion, so exclude.
The study used resting-state fMRI (no task). It does not involve participants completing a social-related task, so it fails the primary inclusion criterion despite including healthy adult controls.

This paper is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis/systematic review). The exclusion criteria specify excluding systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded based on the abstract alone.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task-based social processing). Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls are present, no social task was performed. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.
fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mean/age 24) performing a social-related task (social regulation/handholding, affiliation/attachment). Meets age and task criteria and is not a review.

Participants are children/adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). The study does not report fMRI of healthy adult participants performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study (n=164 healthy adults) using an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) task probing social cognition/attachment. It meets inclusion: social-related task (mentalizing/affiliation/attachment) and healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI (with MEG) while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others/emotion recognition). The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

Original fMRI study examining social cognition (positivity motivation, perceptions of close vs non-close others) in human participants; involves affiliation/attachment constructs (romantic partner) and perception of others. No indication of patient groups or review article. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study used functional MRI during an interactive social task (self- and other-initiated joint/non-joint attention) in 24 healthy adult participants, addressing self- and other-processing constructs. No exclusion criteria are met; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study investigating neural coding of dynamic social attention cues (head turns) in STS, addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) was scanned.

fMRI measured brain activity in healthy adults while they viewed emotional social stimuli (movies). The task probes perception/understanding of others and social interaction networks (TPJ, mPFC, pSTS), matching the review’s social-related processing criteria. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include.

fMRI study of visual perspective-taking (social-cognitive task) with a matched healthy adult control group (20). Task assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Human fMRI study using a social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in large sample of adult men and women; addresses social-affiliation/negative social interaction processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults and study is not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face emotion processing (social cognition) comparing community groups high vs low in social anhedonia. Includes healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (emotion discrimination). Fits inclusion criteria; not a review. Full text can confirm ages if needed.

Abstract reports a single-case fMRI (n=1) with no group of healthy participants or participant ages reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the participant-group criterion.

Study used functional MRI while participants performed a social-affiliation task (shared viewing with a friend), involved healthy adult participants, and reports neural activity related to social sharing. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are described as adolescent boys (internet-addicted and healthy adolescents). The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65 (adults). Although the study uses fMRI on social/self-processing, the healthy sample is not adults per the abstract, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating guilt-related (social) processing and reporting activity in social cognition regions; meets the review’s domain. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports decoding of task fMRI including social cognition tasks using HCP data. While it does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, the HCP dataset typically comprises healthy adults; social-related processing is mentioned. Include for full-text review to confirm task details and that participants meet age/health criteria.

fMRI was used to assess neural correlates of self/other social cognition and tasks involved social-representational processing; study includes a healthy control group. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; full text should be checked for participant ages and task details.

Abstract describes fMRI in patients with schizophrenia during acute episode and after recovery; no mention of a healthy control group or healthy adult participants. Therefore does not meet criterion of including at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

Task-based fMRI study of social (action-intention) processing that includes a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), outside the review's required healthy adult age range (17–65); therefore does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of action observation/execution investigating how observers process others' effort, which maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. The abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy status; likely healthy adults but not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study investigates mentalizing and sensorimotor simulation during listening to literary fiction, addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants appear to be healthy adults, but ages/details aren’t specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm demographics and methods.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion recognition—a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Participants are high genetic risk for schizophrenia (likely unaffected healthy adults). Meets criterion of fMRI during social-related task and includes a healthy adult group; include for full-text review to confirm ages/details.

Primary fMRI study where participants formed impressions of others (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). It reports task-based functional MRI in human participants and is not a review. The abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) demographics.

fMRI study of social cognition matching review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state inclusion of a healthy control group (ages 17-65), so information is insufficient to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and relevant task details.

fMRI study examining empathy/social cognition (perception/understanding of others), fits the review objective. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though age not specified; insufficient detail on demographics warrants full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Real-time fMRI was used while volunteers played the ultimatum game, a social interaction task probing perception/decision about others. Participants are described as volunteers (healthy adults). Study is original empirical fMRI work, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social processing; inclusion requires an fMRI scan while participants complete a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task excludes it.

Primary research fMRI study investigating neural responses to others' physical and emotional pain (Theory of Mind), i.e., perception/understanding of others. Uses healthy participant groups (two groups) and whole-brain and ROI analyses. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face processing (social perception/recognition) comparing an adult clinical case to control subjects; includes at least one group of healthy adult controls. Fits social-related processing domain (perception/understanding of others) and meets participant criteria. Not a review.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although it uses fMRI on a social-related task, it lacks an adult healthy participant group required for inclusion.

Original fMRI study using face-viewing paradigm (social perception/understanding of others) in a continuous sample including adults. Involves healthy participants and is not a review. Abstract does not state exact adult ages but refers to ‘adulthood,’ so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study investigating effects of social gaze on action control (social-related processing). Abstract indicates task manipulating social vs nonsocial cues; meets fMRI + social task criterion. Participant health/age not specified; insufficient detail in abstract to confirm demographics, so include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study investigating empathy/affective responses to human and animal negative scenes—fits ‘perception and understanding of others’ social processing. Includes healthy adult participant groups (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion; full text can confirm exact age range if needed.

The study reports human fMRI data on processing emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), directly addressing the review objective. The abstract suggests human participants but does not state ages/health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy criteria.

fMRI study examining brain responses to dynamic emotional facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others) in young adults; includes matched healthy control group (healthy participants within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets social-related task and healthy-participant criteria.
Study uses resting-state connectivity (no task-based fMRI of social processing). The review requires fMRI during a social-related task; resting-state studies do not meet this inclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating neural processing of social dyadic interactions (perception/understanding of others). Abstract describes multivoxel pattern analysis and results in pSTS and EBA, meeting review objective. No exclusion criteria met. Participant details (health status/ages) not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Reports task-based fMRI of self-evaluation (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct; includes a matched healthy control group (adult participants) alongside patients; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for full data extraction.

fMRI study examining neural activity during general and contextual self-judgments (Perception and Understanding of Self), conducted in healthy adult participants across cultures; empirical study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural responses to others' pain (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Uses task-based fMRI and reports effects of mortality salience on relevant brain regions. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotion processing task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) and included a matched healthy adult control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Whole-brain fMRI was collected while participants performed a social task (viewing group members' faces) probing social cognition and valuation. Study appears to involve healthy adult social networks and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using social-cognition tasks (Theory of Mind and empathy) in healthy adult participants (13 right-handed males, within 17–65). Task directly assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers performing a social interaction task (matching-pennies game) involving perception/understanding of others (anthropomorphism, mind attribution). Meets inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task; healthy participants). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Although oxytocin relates to affiliation, no task-based social processing was measured, so it does not meet the review's inclusion criterion requiring a social task during scanning.

Primary fMRI study examining social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-other differentiation), matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm healthy adult sample and age range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study using point-light displays of human locomotion examines biological motion perception and cerebellum–STS connectivity, addressing perception/understanding of others (a social processing construct). Abstract does not specify participant health or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Study uses task-based fMRI examining processing of human voices—a social communication/perception domain—so it aligns with the review objective. Abstract does not report participant demographics or confirm healthy adult sample; because this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

fMRI was used to measure cortical activation during social cognition tasks (theory of mind). The study includes a healthy control group of age-matched adults. It is an original fMRI study, not a review, and meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of healthy adult subjects passively watching realistic social interactions (social cognition/perception). Uses functional MRI during a social-related task, matches inclusion criteria and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a communicative/collaborative retrieval task; examines social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory of mind) and neural networks of understanding others, meeting the social-related processing and healthy adult criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during negative emotion processing but does not state that the task/stimuli were social (e.g., social interaction, faces, attachment) or give participant details. Insufficient information to determine if it meets the review's 'social-related task' criterion; include for full-text review.

The paper is explicitly a review article (neural systems approaches to the neurogenetics of autism) rather than an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract describes a pharmaco-fMRI study in healthy subjects performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), addressing social processing (mentalizing, reward, attention). It involves functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract but 'healthy subjects' and adult-focused journal make inclusion appropriate for full-text review.

Study reports fMRI during a social cognition task (false-belief ToM) with healthy adult comparison groups (480 adults). It examines social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Others) and is primary research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (dogs). The review requires fMRI studies of social processing in healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study used canine subjects, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study reports an fMRI experiment (Study II) investigating social interaction/gaze and social reward processing, includes a healthy control group alongside cocaine users, and uses a social-related task relevant to social communication/reward. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The abstract describes a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies rather than reporting primary fMRI data from participants. The exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded.

fMRI study of dynamic happy facial expression processing with social interaction cues (social perception/communication). Includes a non-SPD (healthy) control group (n=14), likely adult sample; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) observed risk-taking versus safe actions—an implicit social-cognitive/emotional processing task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are within the 17–65 range and this is not a review. Sufficient information in abstract supports inclusion for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study in multiple sclerosis patients; no task-based social-processing paradigm and no healthy control group (ages 17-65) reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI studies of facial emotion perception (a social-related task). It is not a review/meta-analysis. However the abstract does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm presence and age range of healthy participants.

fMRI study of irony comprehension (social communication) with an adult healthy control group (n=15). Task is social-related processing; includes healthy participants within target age range and is not a review.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception task (plus resting-state), includes a healthy control group (n=21) of adults with no significant demographic differences, and is original research (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition in humans examining mirror neuron and mentalizing systems during social tasks; involves healthy adult participants; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in a sample of healthy adult women performing social perception tasks (judging social relationships from animations). This directly matches the review objective and inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task; healthy participants). No exclusion criteria met.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants engaging in social joint-action tasks (leading, following, mutual). The tasks probe social cognition (mentalizing, social reward, perception of others) during fMRI. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social cognition (effects of emotion and social cognition on legal decision-making; perception/understanding of others) while participants read vignettes. It likely uses healthy adult participants but health status/ages not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm sample meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study (34 participants) examining neural responses to social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing—directly addresses social processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not list participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

Abstract focuses on emotional sentence attribution in schizophrenia but does not state whether healthy control participants were included or explicitly describe an fMRI task. The topic (emotional sentence attribution) is a social-related processing task; because key inclusion elements (presence of healthy adults and fMRI task details) are unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not functional MRI. Although it examines social cognition in healthy adults, it does not meet the requirement of a functional MRI scan, so it should be excluded.

Participants are preschool children (ages 4 and 6); the meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Abstract indicates no adult sample, so study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of affective theory of mind (social processing) using a ToM task; involved 22 healthy participants (21 analyzed). This is primary research (not a review) and meets the criterion of functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. Age not specified but participants are described as healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in adult participants performing social-related tasks (IAT evaluating attitudes toward adultery, go/no-go, and date-rating assessing interest/affiliation). Participants appear to be healthy adults in romantic relationships. This directly fits the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria are met.

fMRI study of emotion recognition using facial expressions (social-related processing/perception of others) in 29 healthy adult participants (within 17–65). Uses functional MRI during social task; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study without participants performing a social-related task; inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing. Although it includes healthy controls, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the review’s criteria.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task involving inference about others' intentions and mirror-neuron–related frontal operculum activation. This directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study identifying brain areas (fMRI) associated with interpersonal synchrony and social affiliation in participants (N=100). This addresses social-related processing (affiliation) in healthy adults and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI ('Hyperscan') during linked social interactions and presents data from a deception game between pairs—clearly an fMRI social task. Participant age/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study on perception of laughter (social communication/perception of others), so directly addresses review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm there is at least one healthy adult (17–65) group.

This study reports fMRI experiments (EmpaToM) investigating empathy and Theory of Mind in healthy adult samples (N=90 and N=178). It directly examines social cognitive processing with task-based functional MRI and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants evaluated personal attributes of themselves (a social/self-processing task). The study addresses perception/understanding of self, involves healthy adult participants (implied), and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study where 55 healthy adult males viewed direct vs. averted gaze (a social-processing task). Sample consists of healthy adults (ages within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
Study used resting-state fMRI without any social-related task; inclusion requires fMRI during a social task. Although healthy controls were included, the absence of a social task excludes it.

Participants were children aged 7–12, not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although it is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy participants, the age criterion for inclusion is not met.

Not a task-based social fMRI study: uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task). Participants are male adolescents (not adults aged 17–65). Therefore does not meet the review’s population or task-based inclusion criteria.
Study uses MEG hyperscanning (dual MEG) and describes an audiovisual link for simultaneous MEG recordings—not functional MRI. Does not meet the required fMRI modality criterion.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (third-person social interaction) while participants watched biological motion; involves (presumably) healthy adult participants and is not a review. Fits the meta-analysis objective of social processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages.

fMRI study of CT-targeted affective (social) touch in 22 healthy adults. The task probes social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and social perception), reports BOLD responses and connectivity in social brain regions. Participants are healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This study reports resting-state fMRI in schizophrenia and examines default network connectivity and theory-of-mind associations. It does not describe a functional MRI scan during a social-related task in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the task-based social processing inclusion criterion.

fMRI BOLD study in 23 healthy participants performing affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks — targets social cognition (Perception/Understanding of Others). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and other details.

fMRI study examining observation of social interactions and gaze modulation—addresses social processing. Abstract indicates task involved observing social vs individual actions during scanning. Participant health/ages not specified; include for full-text review to confirm sample demographics.

The study used resting-state fMRI after cTBS and did not involve a task-based social processing paradigm. Although SI is linked to action observation, no social-related task was performed during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI scan while participants completed a social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation showing changes in networks linked to social cognition and theory of mind. It is unclear whether a specific social-related task was used or if data were resting-state, and participant ages/health are not fully specified. Insufficient information in abstract—include for full-text review.
Non-human (rat) study using resting-state fMRI under anesthesia; no social-related task and participants are not healthy adult humans (age 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind and the medial prefrontal cortex but does not specify whether an fMRI was used, participant characteristics, or ages. No exclusion criteria met; insufficient methodological detail to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI scanning and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study probing social-related processing (affiliation/attachment, empathy) by having participants imagine loved-ones vs strangers; involves healthy adult participants (no clinical groups reported) and is an original research article, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Primary study using fMRI while clinicians performed a social task (doctor–patient interaction/treatment) involving empathy and reward processing. Participants are healthy adult MDs (ages 25–37) within 17–65. Study is original research (not a review) and clearly addresses social processing constructs (empathy, social interaction). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study with healthy young adult participants (n=55) performing social-related tasks (attachment-related erotic scenes and fearful social scenes), directly addressing social processing; not a review/meta-analysis.

Primary data from fMRI BOLD collected while healthy adult participants (25 females) performed a social cognition task about kin and friends (affiliation/attachment/social understanding). Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of self-reference vs reference to others directly examines social-related processing (self/other perception). Abstract does not specify participant health status or age range; insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

Empirical fMRI study with healthy adult mothers performing a social-affiliation task (viewing own vs unfamiliar child/dog), tapping attachment/affiliation constructs relevant to the review objective; not a review/meta-analysis.

Study reports fMRI BOLD response to an eyes task probing social cognition/theory of mind, meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not clearly state participant ages or explicitly confirm a healthy adult group (offspring may be at-risk), so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The study uses fMRI during self- and other-reflection (social-related processing). However, the abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the presence of healthy adults is required and this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults (18 right-handed male volunteers, within 17–65) performing a validated social-cognition/ToM task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) during functional MRI. Study reports neural responses to social processing; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a gaze-following social-attention task examining social processes (in-group/out-group, social dominance). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original research article, not a review. Meets the review’s fMRI + social processing + healthy adult criteria.

fMRI study where participants (adults) were scanned while thinking about 16 social interactions (social-related processing). Includes a matched healthy control group of adults (meets age criterion). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social processing: perception/understanding of others) comparing euthymic bipolar patients with healthy subjects. It therefore involves a social-related fMRI task and includes a healthy adult comparison group. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study manipulating group membership while participants judged actions of in-group vs out-group—clearly a social-processing task (group affiliation, perception of others). Conducted in healthy participants (typical fMRI sample) and meets inclusion of social-related fMRI in adults; abstract is sufficient to include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs. competitive interactions, directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or age range; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) and other eligibility details.
Participants are patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment; no healthy adult control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (ages 17–65).

fMRI was used during an empathy-for-pain task (social-related construct: perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy younger participant group (ages 20–30), meeting the 17–65 criterion. No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract describes fMRI connectivity in ASD vs typically developing adolescents but does not specify participant ages or that a social-related task was performed (could be resting-state). Because information is insufficient to confirm adult (17–65) healthy participants and task-based social processing, include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study investigating cerebro-cerebellar limbic networks in MCI and AD patients and healthy controls; it does not involve a task-based social processing paradigm. Thus it does not meet the requirement of fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study of social cognition (empathy/perspective-taking) with 18 healthy adult participants; task involves perception and understanding of self and others (pain empathy), matching inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating perception of others’ hand actions (Perception and Understanding of Others) during observation tasks; includes a healthy adult group (n=31). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Empirical fMRI study using an interactive Domino task that elicits mentalizing (a social-processing construct) and includes a healthy control group (typically developed adults aged 18–34). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study presenting dynamic and static facial expressions (social perception of others) — a social-related task. Includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group (healthy participants). Abstract lacks explicit participant age range, so full text review needed to confirm ages 17–65.

Abstract describes an event-related fMRI study directly examining neural processing of social versus nonsocial gestures, matching the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant demographics or explicit confirmation of healthy adults aged 17–65, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility. No exclusion criteria (e.g., reviews) are met.

fMRI study manipulating social vs nonsocial working memory (social-related task) with neural effects in social cognition/face-processing regions. Meets review objective and is not a review. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

Participants are adolescents (study compares adolescents with TBI to typically developing adolescents). The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; adolescent samples fall outside the age range, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (a social-related construct: Perception and Understanding of Self) that includes a healthy control group of adults; task involves trait judgments about self/mother/president; meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

fMRI study using a second-order Theory of Mind task (social processing) with a healthy control group (25 adults) included; participants fall within adult age range and the study is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using MVPA to examine neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Abstract describes a social-related task and neural data but does not specify participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm the sample meets healthy adult (17-65) criterion.

Task-based fMRI study examining mirror neuron system and modulation by emotion (components of social cognition and perception of others). Abstract describes fMRI repetition suppression to action–shape pairs preceded by emotional images. Participant health/age not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.
Study participants were children and adolescents (ages 10–17) with no group of healthy adults in the 17–65 range, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

Study examined fMRI responses in preschool-aged children with ASD (and compared to typically developing children likely also pediatric). No healthy adult (age 17–65) group is present, so it does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

Event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-related task) with 28 healthy control participants matched to ASD group. Task assesses social cognition/perception of others; includes healthy adults (matched for age), meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis or excluded study type.

Original fMRI study examining social cognition (representing what another person sees/joint attention). Participants viewed stimuli while scanned; task is social-related and not a review. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, but participants appear to be healthy adults—include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract examines body-checking in anorexia nervosa using fMRI and focuses on self-perception, a social-related construct. However the abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 26 adult participants performing empathy-evoking (social) tasks; investigates social cognition (temporal pole modulation during empathy) in healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

This article is a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide primary fMRI data on social tasks in healthy adults.

Participants are adolescents aged 9–17 (N=34); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the age criterion for adult participants, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (n=20) performing a social-related task (simulating/sharing a third person’s feelings while viewing others’ actions). Fits review objective (social processing: perception/understanding of others) and meets age/health criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports dual-fMRI during cooperative and competitive social interactions, i.e., a functional MRI task probing social processing. No information on participant health or ages is provided, but no exclusion criteria are met. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics (healthy adults, ages 17–65).

The study reports fMRI in humans (healthy adults) examining understanding of actions at different levels (why/how), engaging mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks—falls under social processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of mentalizing (social cognition) with a healthy control group of adult males; task involves reflective mentalizing about self/other, matching the social-processing constructs. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Study used fMRI while participants performed the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Sample includes healthy young adult women (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Study uses BOLD fMRI during a social-related task (affiliation vs isolation), compares healthy younger and older adults, and is an original empirical study (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in young, healthy participants using an incentive delay task with social reward (anticipation and feedback), directly addressing social reward processing. It involves healthy adult participants and is original research, not a review—meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to visible and invisible neutral and fearful faces (facial expression/identity processing), a social-perception task in observers. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI and investigates language-network connectivity of the anterior temporal lobe, not social-related processing or a social task. Although participants are healthy adults, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face-voice integration (social perception/communication) in 20 participants; not a review. Abstract does not specify ages but likely healthy adults—include for full-text review to confirm age range and health criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in normal adult volunteers viewing videos of positive and negative social encounters, directly examining social processing. Healthy adults are included and task is social; not a review. Include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to examine perception of social scenes (interacting person dyads), which fits the social-related processing objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) using event-related BOLD; includes a healthy adult control group (n=21) alongside patient group; task assesses social-related processing (face encoding/recognition). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders; abstract does not indicate any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65). Although the task is social (self/other judgments), lack of healthy sample excludes the study.

Randomized, within-subject fMRI study in 40 healthy adult males measuring neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (a social/affiliation task). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult men performing a social-related task (viewing faces with different gaze orientations during gender judgments) assessing social cognition (fear recognition, theory of mind). Participants are healthy adults; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Although an fMRI study of a social task (joint attention), the sample consists of children and adolescents with no healthy adult group (age 17–65) reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group 17–65, so this study is excluded.

fMRI study with 25 healthy adult participants (within 17–65). Task involves viewing natural and color-manipulated faces to probe facial color processing, which is social communication/perception of others (emotion/health cues). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants read sentences eliciting guilt and embarrassment (social/self-conscious emotions) — a social-related task; sample includes 19 healthy volunteers (adult participants). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
Participants are preadolescents (age 11). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Therefore the study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of social understanding/social processing; includes a matched healthy adult control group (adults), so meets inclusion of fMRI social task and healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during a social interactive task (including in-group/out-group interactions), targets social cognition, and is an original empirical study (not a review). While participant ages/health are not explicitly stated, the study appears to involve healthy adult subjects; include for full‑text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract reports only schizophrenia participants (two patient groups: AT+SCT and computer games); no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is described. Although an fMRI emotion-recognition task was used, the absence of any healthy adults means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are drawn from an adjudicated forensic inpatient population (psychotic and nonpsychotic criminal offenders). No group of healthy (non-forensic, nonpsychiatric) adults is included; thus it fails the criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Study reports fMRI during a social reflection task (self/other judgments) in 22 healthy subjects, matching ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’ constructs. Not a review; includes at least one healthy participant group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract examines oxytocin effects on neural basis of face processing (a social-related task) and likely uses fMRI, but only reports adults with Asperger syndrome; it does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group; information is insufficient from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI whole-brain analysis of agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation relates to social cognition (perception/understanding of self and others). Abstract lacks explicit participant health/age details, so include for full-text review.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult subjects performing trustworthiness judgments of faces, a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others). It reports task-related BOLD responses and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Study uses functional MRI to examine neural responses during a social interaction task (cyber-ball) probing social inclusion/exclusion—clearly social processing. Although the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, it reports an experimental participant sample; criteria met or insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant health/age and other details.

Hyperscanning fMRI during a real-time joint attention social interaction task examines cross-brain connectivity related to social behavior in human dyads. Study involves healthy participants and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study in healthy adults examining self- and other-recognition (face and name), addressing social cognition (perception/understanding of self/others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria as described in abstract.

Neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observing social interactions; uses imaging of mirror/mentalizing networks, addressing social perception. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; includes a social-related task. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI modality details and participant age range/health status.

Title indicates this is a meta-analytic MKDA of fMRI studies (multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Therefore excluded based on abstract information.

Study focuses on children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS) and likely pediatric participants; does not include healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review. Although it uses fMRI and a social stimulus (fearful faces), the age/sample criterion is not met.

This study investigates white-matter and functional connectivity supporting memory retrieval in VLPFC, not social-related processing. The abstract describes memory and anatomical connectivity analyses, not social tasks or social cognition constructs, so it does not meet the review objective.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of neural responses to social interaction images in remitted major depression and implicitly compares to healthy controls. It addresses social-related processing in adults and is not a review. Includes insufficient sample-age detail but meets inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study examining automatic perception of cooperative vs noncooperative social behavior (social cognition). Includes a healthy matched control group (n=19), adult participants implied, and is an original research article, not a review.

Abstract does not specify use of functional MRI or whether a healthy control group was included. Topic (imitation/social understanding) is within social processing, but insufficient methodological detail in abstract to confirm fMRI and healthy adults. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

All participants were individuals with schizophrenia (n=22); no healthy control/healthy participant group (age 17–65) is reported. Although an fMRI emotion-recognition task was used, the study fails the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study examining mimicry regulation using facial stimuli (emotional expression and group membership) — a social-affective task relevant to affiliation/understanding others. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study of perception of nonverbal emotional social signals (voice and face), addressing social processing/perception of others in individual subjects. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study of social-related face processing (dynamic face stimuli) meets topic criterion. Abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; information is insufficient to confirm exclusion. Per instructions, include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy participants.
Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy participants reading a suspenseful literary text; neural responses linked to brain areas associated with social cognition and predictive inference, which fits ‘perception and understanding of others’/social-related processing. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract lacks exact ages but provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of joint attention—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports participants underwent fMRI and does not indicate a review or an exclusively clinical sample. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), not functional MRI, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI while participants completed a social-related task. Although it examines face memory (a social domain) in healthy adults, inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task; this criterion is not met.

This is a narrative review of seven MRI studies conducted in ADHD samples (children/adolescents), not a primary fMRI study of social tasks in healthy adults. The abstract indicates clinical (ADHD) groups and no healthy adult (17–65) participants; it is also a review article rather than original data, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining impression updating—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports fMRI whole-brain results. Participant health/age not specified; per screening rules, include when information is insufficient for exclusion so full-text can confirm sample characteristics.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time mutual eye contact (a social communication/perception task) in adult human pairs. Involves functional MRI during a social-related task and reports neural activations; not a review/meta-analysis. Participants described as human adults (meets age criterion). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in which participants performed an IAT involving faces/names of politicians (social perception and evaluation of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and measures neural responses during a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (watching a narrator using co-speech gestures). Assesses social communication/perception constructs and reports neural processing; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study examines gene–environment effects on response inhibition in adolescents, not social cognition; abstract does not mention fMRI or a social-related task, and participants are adolescents (not clearly within 17–65 healthy adults). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes background/intrinsic functional connectivity (resting-state) analyses linking self-experience and self-other processing; there is no mention of an experimental social-related task being performed during fMRI. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not meet the inclusion requirement of a task-based social processing fMRI.

Abstract describes network topology related to familial risk for psychotic disorder and does not report an fMRI social-related task or social processing constructs. It appears focused on connectivity metrics (likely resting-state) rather than social-affiliation/communication tasks, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study with no participant performing a social-related task. Although it mentions networks linked to social cognition, inclusion requires task-based social processing. Therefore exclude based on lack of a social task.

fMRI study investigating perception of different laughter types—a social communication/social cognition task—meeting the review objective. Abstract confirms task-related fMRI but does not specify participant ages or health status; include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social task: learning about others' generosity (perception/understanding of others). Uses functional MRI and directly addresses social processing; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Functional MRI was used while participants viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others). The study includes healthy adult control groups alongside ASD participants (adult samples within target age range). It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder; the abstract does not report any healthy control group (age 17–65). Thus it fails the inclusion requirement of at least one healthy participant group.

Participants are children (boys), including one with autism and typically developing child controls; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included, so study does not meet the age/group inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining communicative speech production (social communication) in normal subjects; task contrasts communication vs description and probes social-interaction processing. Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm demographics.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants performing a Theory of Mind (social) task (REMICS), directly investigating social cognitive processes (mental state inference and contextual adjustments). Participants are healthy and within the eligible age range; the paper is empirical fMRI research (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a comparative review of face perception across species and behavioral experiments; not an original human fMRI study. It appears to be a review article rather than a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult humans, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Primary research reporting fMRI studies using a social cognition (Theory of Mind) task (Why/How) in human participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract describes three fMRI experiments and a task that probes perception/understanding of others, consistent with inclusion criteria. Participant health appears to be healthy adults (single-subject localization), so include for full-text review to confirm ages and sample details.

fMRI study of cortical processing of vocal (socially relevant) sounds, addressing social-related processing. Abstract implies comparison with typical activation but does not explicitly state presence/age of healthy control group; insufficient detail—include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult participants (17–65).

Study involves adolescents with autism and reports developmental findings in children/adolescents; abstract does not indicate a healthy adult (age 17–65) sample or control group. Therefore it does not meet the review criterion of including healthy adults.

fMRI study of social perception (approach with angry/happy facial expressions) addresses social-related processing and reports brain activations. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify healthy adults (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports resting-state fMRI connectivity for ASD biomarker classification, not a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. No indication of healthy adult participants performing social tasks. Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Sample consists of children and adolescents aged 8–17 with no adult (17–65) participant group. Review seeks studies of healthy adults age 17–65, so population criterion not met.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in ultra-high-risk (UHR) subjects rather than an fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. The abstract describes resting-state connectivity and UHR participants; no social task or clear healthy adult group is reported.

fMRI study using a face perception task (social cognition) with emotional/neutral stimuli; includes a healthy control group alongside social phobia patients; involves adult participants and is an original empirical study, not a review.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task); inclusion requires a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Although oxytocin and social cognition are discussed, no task-based social processing was performed.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to dynamic and static social stimuli (faces, point-light displays, social interactions). Includes a typically developing (healthy) adolescent control group, but ages not specified; cannot confirm 17–65 criterion from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and extract relevant data.

fMRI study examining processing of social reputation (a social-related task) in male and female subjects; involves healthy participants and directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 20 healthy human participants performing a social task (mimicry modulated by eye contact), directly investigating social processing; not a review. Include for full-text data extraction.

Study reports fMRI of social cognitive tasks and tests neural networks for social cognition in patients and their unaffected siblings. 'Unaffected siblings' implies a healthy adult group performing social-related tasks, matching inclusion criteria (fMRI during social processing; healthy participants). Abstract is not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and task details.

Participants are domestic dogs, not human adults. Inclusion requires fMRI studies with healthy human participants aged 17–65; this study used non-human animals, so it does not meet participant criteria.

fMRI study assessing neural responses during a social interaction simulation focused on friendship (affiliation/attachment), reporting results from 28 healthy participants. Targets social-related processing (empathy, reward) in humans and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria for full-text extraction.

Abstract describes neural responses during evaluation of face approachability—a social-processing task—but does not specify use of fMRI or participant ages. Topic fits review objective but information is insufficient to confirm imaging and sample; include for full-text review.

Empirical fMRI study in which participants (presumably healthy adults) performed social-related tasks (emotion perception/ social communication: discriminating valence and rating emotional targets). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides task and imaging details meeting inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining neural responses to threats to self, familiar friend, and stranger—clearly addresses social processing (empathy/affiliation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm it meets the healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI in 13 PTSD patients only; no healthy adult control group (age 17–65) is mentioned. Review requires at least one group of healthy participants, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used task-based fMRI of perspective-taking (social cognition). However, the healthy participant group are adolescents aged 12–19; abstract doesn’t confirm whether any healthy participants are ≥17. Age eligibility for adults (17–65) is unclear, so include for full-text review to determine age eligibility and extract data.

fMRI study examining affiliative (kinship-related) social scenarios in humans, directly addressing social-related processing (Affiliation/Attachment). Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages/health not specified; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

Primary fMRI study (36 healthy adult subjects) examining neural responses and effective connectivity during observation of cooperative and affective social interactions — a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task; healthy adult group). Not a review or meta-analysis.
This paper is a meta-analysis/synthesis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with human participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) to examine trait self-esteem, not an fMRI scan acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based social processing; thus it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Participants are children (high-functioning ASD and typically developing children); the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65). The abstract does not report any adult healthy participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of prayer in a group of (presumably healthy) adult Danish Christians showing recruitment of social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus). This is a task-based fMRI investigation of social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

Abstract does not clearly state whether at least one healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or explicitly describe that participants underwent an fMRI during a social-related task. It likely involves fMRI social cognition measures but provides insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning others’ trustworthiness) in healthy younger and older adults. It involves social cognition (perception/understanding of others) and reports original data (not a review). Although exact ages aren’t listed, the presence of younger adult participants makes it likely at least one group falls within 17–65. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI using a false belief (social cognition) task assessing understanding of others’ mental states. Although participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, the study reports correlational analyses of personality in subjects (likely healthy adults); abstract lacks exclusionary criteria. Insufficient demographic detail for full certainty — include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Study uses real-time fMRI combined with EEG targeting social communication (right pSTS), matching the review’s social processing focus. Abstract lacks details on participant health/ages and explicit task description, so full-text is needed to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65) and task-based fMRI. Include for full-text screening.
fMRI social-processing study but participants are children (unaffected siblings and children with ASD); does not include healthy adult participants aged 17–65 required by review criteria.
