Abstract is insufficient to determine eligibility: it does not state whether an fMRI social-related task was used (may be resting-state connectivity) nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Study focuses on ASD and ADHD co-occurrence. Include for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and presence of healthy participants.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) and focused on individuals with autism; no evidence of a healthy adult task-based group. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) in adults; includes a healthy control group matched on age (healthy participants aged as adults), meeting the requirement for at least one healthy adult group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study using event-related paradigm of gesture planning/execution (social communication/social action), includes a healthy adult control group (matched; likely ages 17–65), and is not a review. Abstract clearly describes social-related processing and healthy participants, meeting inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study examining self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition constructs: perception/understanding of self and others). Appears to test participants (likely healthy adults) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Abstract does not report task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Study uses resting-state connectivity, structural covariance, and meta-analytic connectivity modeling to characterize the left anterior insula, not an in-scanner social task.

The abstract reports fMRI connectivity in an ASD clinical sample and does not describe a social-related task or inclusion of a healthy adult task group. It likely uses resting-state or task-free connectivity and focuses on clinical severity, so it does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of self- and other-referential perspective-taking (social processing) with 24 typically developed adult controls (healthy adults) and ASD group. Task and population meet inclusion criteria; not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI hyperscanning study of joint attention, a social-related task (social interaction). Participant health/age not specified in abstract; insufficient to confirm healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Original fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) with healthy control group participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages aren’t stated in the abstract, controls are reported and task is social-related, so it meets inclusion; include for full-text review.

Abstract examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct) and reports neural activation; however the abstract does not clearly state use of fMRI nor presence of healthy control group. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

Abstract addresses perception of emotional faces (a social-related task linked to amygdala) but does not explicitly state use of functional MRI or presence of a healthy control group. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine fMRI methods and whether healthy adults (17–65) were studied.

fMRI experiment probing emotion recognition and gaze integration (social cognition/mentalizing). Includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within 17–65 inclusion range). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI and behavioral measures of social cognition (emotion/sarcasm recognition), not a task-based fMRI scan during social-related processing. Although healthy controls were included, the key inclusion requirement—functional MRI while completing a social-related task—is not met.

Study examines children and adolescents with autism and integrates functional/structural connectivity; does not report fMRI in healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Therefore does not meet the requirement of including healthy adults.

Abstract reports correlational analysis relating SRS-A scores to functional connectivity (cingulo-insular/pregenual ACC) in neurotypical adults, with no indication of an fMRI social task. Likely resting-state connectivity rather than task-based social processing; thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study of fearful face-processing (social-related task: perception/understanding of others). Includes a matched healthy adult control group alongside Asperger/HFA group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports oxytocin effects on processing of socially relevant cues in the human ventral tegmental area, which fits the social-related processing domain. However the abstract does not specify use of functional MRI or participant age/health details. Because key methodological/participant information is missing, include for full-text review to determine whether it used fMRI and healthy adult participants.

Abstract investigates neural correlates of facial emotion processing (social processing) in individuals at risk for psychosis; likely an fMRI study of face perception. The abstract does not explicitly state imaging modality or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Due to insufficient information in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm fMRI use and presence of a healthy adult group.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task). The review requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy control groups are included, no task-based social processing was performed, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in adolescent patients and controls (not an active social-related task) and participants are adolescents (early-onset schizophrenia), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet task-based social processing or healthy adult population criteria.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotion perception task (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy control group of adults without MDD. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults based on the abstract.

Study sample comprises pediatric/adolescent participants with social anxiety (not adults); abstract does not indicate a healthy adult (age 17–65) group. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion age/sample criteria for the review.

Abstract reports oxytocin effects on neural activity (anterior insula) related to approach behavior to positive social stimuli, implying neuroimaging during a social task in humans. However the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI methods or participant health/ages. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with healthy adult bilinguals using fingerspelling (sign language), which may fall under 'Social Communication'. Abstract centers on phonological memory rather than explicit social processing; information is insufficient to rule out relevance. Include for full-text review to confirm whether task meets social-related constructs.

Abstract reports fMRI of a non-clinical (healthy) cohort performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social (Theory of Mind) task, meeting the review objective. Age range of healthy participants is not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) and multimodal imaging to predict cognitive/symptom scores. Although it predicts a social cognition score, there was no functional MRI during a social-related task, so it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing.

This study examines resting-state and diffusion imaging correlates of visuospatial working memory in adolescents with ASD and typically developing adolescents. It does not involve task-based fMRI of social-related processing, and participants are adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s population or task criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task) in adolescents with ASD; does not include a task-based social processing paradigm or a healthy adult (17–65) group required by the review objective. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI studies comparing neural responses to person-related (famous people) and social abstract words versus other categories, indicating social-related processing tasks. Study uses human participants (implied healthy adults) and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses an fMRI precision visuomotor (sensorimotor) task in individuals with ASD, not a social-processing task, and participants are clinical (ASD) rather than healthy adults. Does not meet review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study used functional MRI during a theory-of-mind task (social cognition: Perception and Understanding of Others) in 109 healthy adult volunteers, directly matching the review objective and inclusion criteria. It is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Original research using fMRI to study perspective selection (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Abstract investigates fMRI connectivity related to emotional processing in Huntington’s disease but does not state whether task-based social-related fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Emotional processing may fall under social cognition, but details are insufficient—include for full-text review to confirm.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing; although participants are healthy adults, no social task was administered, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports BOLD measures of the face-processing network in healthy adults but does not specify that fMRI was acquired during a social-related task; insufficient information to confirm task-based social processing. Include for full-text review to determine task vs resting-state and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating processing of communicative (social) gestures and mentalizing/mirror systems during observation and imitation—fits ‘social communication’ and fMRI modality. Involves 20 participants (presumably healthy adults). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents (8–15) with ASD and controls; no task-based social processing paradigm; sample not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the review’s requirement for task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing (encoding with social faces) includes a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (described as “boys”), so inclusion criterion of adult participants (17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify ages and eligibility.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and examines youth with autism rather than healthy adults aged 17–65; therefore does not meet the review’s task-based social processing and population criteria.

This article is a review summarizing and critically evaluating brain-imaging studies (not an original fMRI study). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses. The abstract also does not report fMRI social-processing tasks in healthy adults.

The abstract investigates social-emotional action control relevant to social processing, but does not specify use of functional MRI or confirm sample are healthy adults (17–65). Insufficient information on imaging modality and participant details; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI social-task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Topic concerns social interactive processing and likely involves fMRI, but information is insufficient to confirm eligibility. Include for full-text review to determine task details and presence of healthy controls.

Study used fMRI during a social-cognition task (modified Sally-Anne) assessing inference of others' social emotions; includes a matched healthy control group (17 typically developing males). Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm they meet 17–65 age criterion.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm and focuses on ASD; does not report task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adults as required by inclusion criteria.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: The study meets some criteria (fMRI in healthy adult participants engaging social-related tasks such as theory-of-mind, face/voice perception, biological motion; ages 19–31). However, the reported task activation results were obtained from analyses restricted to a bilateral STS mask (i.e., region-constrained/ROI analyses) rather than whole-brain voxelwise results. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain analyses (not only ROI-restricted results). Because the primary reported activation results are STS-masked and thus constitute ROI-restricted analyses, the study does not meet the whole-brain analysis criterion and must be excluded.

This study used functional MRI while participants completed a social-related task (social vs non-social incentive delay with facial cues and feedback). It includes a healthy control group (N=24; ages 19–36) with results reported separately. Analyses include voxel-wise whole-brain second-level models (event-related, full-brain contrasts reported for Models 1 and 3) in addition to ROI analyses; thus it is not ROI-only. The task and contrasts target social processing (anticipation and evaluative social feedback), matching the review constructs. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social fMRI task, healthy adult participants within age range, and whole-brain analyses reported).

Study uses fMRI and the Cyberball social ostracism/support paradigm (a social-related task). Participants are healthy adults (undergraduates; mean age 19.85) with a majority (37/46) having no Axis I disorders; data include whole-brain voxel-wise analyses (EX–IN and SUP–EX contrasts) and regression analyses across social anxiety scores. Whole-brain results are reported (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain regressions) and supported by ROI analyses, satisfying the requirement that whole-brain analyses are available. Although a minority of participants met criteria for SAD, the sample includes healthy participants and the reported whole-brain findings pertain to the sample and to social anxiety as a continuous measure rather than being limited to a clinical group. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball ball‑toss paradigm (a social interaction task) in healthy adult participants (data analyzed from 31 adults, mean age ~21). The authors performed whole‑brain group-level analyses using SPM8 (paired t-tests with cluster-level FWE correction) and report whole‑brain activation results (right ventral striatum, precuneus) for social interaction contrasts. Although they extracted beta values from spheres for individual difference analyses, the main statistical inferences are based on whole‑brain analyses. No clinical or patient‑only groups are reported and healthy participants’ results are presented separately. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task during fMRI; healthy adults aged 17–65; whole‑brain analyses reported) and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates the neural basis of understanding others’ regret (a social cognition task: perception and understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (two studies; n=24 each; ages within 19–31.8), meeting the age and health criteria. Analysis used whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (SPM5), conjunction and parametric whole-brain contrasts thresholded at p<0.001 uncorrected and reported cluster results across the brain (not restricted to ROIs). Results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a whole-brain fMRI study of a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliation/aggression — a social-related process (interaction, perception of others, social behavior). Participants are healthy adults (n=15, mean age 22.3), within the 17–65 range, with results reported for the healthy group. Analyses reported are whole-brain random-effects group analyses and whole-brain parametric modulation maps (cluster-corrected); results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. Although sample size is small and participants are all male (limits generalizability), these do not violate inclusion criteria. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

This is a dual-fMRI (functional MRI) hyperscanning study measuring brain responses of healthy adult participants (N=44; mean age 22.4, within 17–65) while they performed an interactive social task (cooperation/competition in the pattern game). Analyses include whole-brain GLM and group-level random-effects inference (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (randomize/TFCE), not limited to ROI results. Healthy participants are reported separately and no clinical-only groups are analyzed. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain analyses reported.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (comprehension of speech acts: Naming vs Requesting) in healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–41). The task clearly targets social-related processing (social communication, perception/understanding of others). The paper reports whole-brain random-effects analyses with FDR correction (group-level whole-brain contrasts) and also uses ROI/SVC (allowed since whole-brain results are present). Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply. Hence the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (final samples: Explicit Task n=16, Implicit Task n=17; ages 21–46 within 17–65) investigating social cognition—specifically attribution of emotions/mental states (theory of mind/understanding of others) to human and non-human faces. The experiment involved in-scanner tasks (explicit emotion attribution and an implicit one-back with faces) and reports whole-brain group-level analyses (flexible factorial ANOVA, conjunctions, cluster-level FWE-correction) alongside ROI analyses. Thus it meets: 1) fMRI during a social-related task (Perception/Understanding of Others), 2) healthy adult participants within age range, and 3) whole-brain results reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not limited to clinical samples). Therefore the study should be included in the review.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (self-touch vs other-touch) that probes perception/processing of self and others (social touch). It includes a healthy control group of neurotypical adults (n=30, mean age ~23.7) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (FWE-corrected whole-brain comparisons for other‑touch and group contrasts) in addition to ROI analyses, so it is not ROI-only. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Although the study also reports data from an ADHD group, healthy participant results are presented independently. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study using a social judgment task (acceptance/rejection feedback) — a social-related processing paradigm. It includes a healthy control group (n=20, females, mean age 28.15) with results reported separately (within-group activations for controls are presented). Analyses are whole-brain voxel-wise second-level tests (SPM8 two-sample t-tests across the brain) with cluster-level correction (Alphasim/Family Wise Error correction) rather than ROI-only reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-affective task (viewing an empathic fearful film) and includes a healthy adult group (ages within 17–65) with results reported separately, the reported analyses focus on predefined networks/nodes (ES and ToM) and network-cohesion (NCI) computed from voxel clusters derived from prior meta-analyses. The paper does not present whole-brain voxelwise statistical analyses; instead it uses ROI/network-based connectivity and averaged node signals. The review’s inclusion criterion requires whole-brain analyses (studies reporting only ROI/network analyses must be excluded). Therefore this study does not meet the whole-brain analysis requirement and should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: healthy adult participants (final N=18 female, mean age 21), task is a social one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma assessing social cooperation during fMRI, and the paper reports whole-brain analyses (random-effects flexible factorial, cluster-level FWE correction reported) in addition to ROI analyses. No exclusion criteria apply (results are not limited to clinical populations and are not ROI-only). Therefore the study should be included in the review of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study used functional MRI during a task where participants listened to and processed vocal emotional (prosody) stimuli — a form of social communication/perception of others’ emotions, matching the review’s social-related constructs. Participants were healthy adults (N=36, ages 20–35). Analyses were whole-brain: FC computed across the Power-264 atlas with graph-theoretical measures (nodal, global, and interregional whole-brain results), not limited to ROIs. No exclusion criteria are met (not solely ROI analyses; healthy group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=12, ages 20–32) that explicitly examines person-related (social) conceptual processing vs. non-social categories (buildings, hammers). The task engages social cognition (learning facts about people) and the paper reports whole-brain voxelwise analyses with multiple-comparison correction (conjunction analyses and cluster-size correction across the brain), not only ROI results (although ROI analyses are also presented). Participants are healthy and within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study fits the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=37 analyzed; ages 18–25). The task investigates the urge to imitate meaningless actions—a form of social processing related to perception and understanding of others and imitation. Analyses were whole-brain (SPM8, voxel-wise parametric modulation, cluster correction reported) rather than ROI-only. Healthy participant results are reported separately; no patient-only data. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult group within age range, and whole-brain analyses. Confidence high given clear reporting of methods and whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning about others’ preference similarity and impression formation), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 25.1, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social (tracking other agents’ preferences relative to the self). Results report whole-brain, cluster-corrected analyses (conjunctions and contrasts with whole-brain significance thresholds); findings are not limited to ROI analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in which healthy adult controls (n=10) performed a social-perception task (biological motion categorization—Perception and Understanding of Others). fMRI data were collected while participants judged biological vs. scrambled/perturbed human motion. Although main analyses focus on ROIs (STSp and MT), the paper also reports whole-brain analyses (block-design localizer contrasts used to localize STSp/MT across the whole brain and an exploratory whole-brain search for hits vs. correct rejections), so results are not limited to ROI-only reporting. Healthy participant results are reported separately. Participants are adults and within the target age range. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI of social interaction (SI) recognition (perception/understanding of others) using point-light displays. It includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8 years, within 17–65) with results presented separately by age group. Analyses are whole-brain (SPM8 second-level random-effects; peak- and cluster-level thresholds; FWE correction reported), not ROI-only. Therefore it meets: (1) social-related task, (2) includes healthy adult participants in the target age range with separate reporting, and (3) whole-brain analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Participants are children/adolescents (age range 9–17.6 years, mean 13.66), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although the study includes a typically developing (healthy) control group with separate results and uses whole-brain fMRI analyses of a social cognition (sarcasm) task, the sample does not meet the age criterion for healthy adults. Therefore the study does not satisfy the inclusion criteria for this meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study using the HCP social cognition (Animated Triangles) paradigm (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (N=25) with results reported separately from first-episode schizophrenia patients. Analyses are whole-brain (SPM12, reporting FWE whole-brain corrected results and conjunction analyses), not ROI-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (two experiments; participants aged 18–34 and 18–30). The tasks probe perception and understanding of others (visual perception of social interactions, competition vs. cooperation), fitting the review’s social-related constructs. The paper reports whole-brain group analyses (surface-based random-effects group analysis, FDR-corrected results; whole-brain contrasts and figures), meeting the requirement for whole-brain results; ROI analyses are also reported but do not preclude inclusion. Participants are healthy and within the 17–65 age range. No analyses are restricted to clinical groups only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports an fMRI experiment (Experiment 2) in healthy adult participants (N=17, mean age 22, within 17–65) performing a mentalising/theory-of-mind task — clearly social cognition (Perception and Understanding of Others). Imaging methods include whole-brain voxelwise analyses using SPM2 with normalization to MNI space and cluster-level thresholding yielding whole-brain corrected results (P<0.05). Results are not limited to ROI analyses. No clinical-only groups; participants are healthy. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study reports fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=21 initial, final sample within age range 22–38) performing a social-related task (perception of others’ head turns, a social attention/gaze processing paradigm). The analysis includes both hypothesis-driven ROI MVPA and exploratory whole-brain analyses (full gray-matter volume and whole-brain univariate results are reported), so results are not limited to ROI-only. Participants were healthy and results for healthy participants are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task; healthy adults 17–65; whole-brain analyses reported). No exclusion criteria are met.

The study reports fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants (female, ages 20–33) completed a social-related task (sharing emotional picture viewing with a friend vs alone), addressing affiliation/social sharing. Whole-brain analyses are reported (exploratory whole-brain contrasts with cluster-level correction via AlphaSim) in addition to ROI analyses; thus results are not limited to ROI-only reporting. Participants are healthy and results for this group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20 scanned; mean age 25.7, no history of neurological/psychiatric disorder) that examined social-emotional processing (guilt memories vs hypothetical social scenarios). The task involves social cognition/perception of others (guilt, moral violations) and thus fits the review constructs. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (thresholded at p<0.001, extent 23 voxels) as well as small-volume corrections; whole-brain results are presented, so it is not ROI-only. Results for the healthy sample are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not limited to clinical groups). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (final N=12, mean age 26) that investigates perception/understanding of others’ actions (ability to infer others’ applied grip force), which fits the review construct “Perception and Understanding of Others.” The experiment uses whole-brain analyses (SPM12 voxel-wise GLM with parametric modulation; voxel-wise thresholds and cluster correction) and reports whole-brain results (and SUIT cerebellar analyses). Results for healthy participants are reported separately and no clinical-only group is used. Analyses are not restricted to ROIs. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within the age range, and whole-brain results provided.

Study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–27) while they listened to literary stories and a Theory-of-Mind localizer, targeting mentalizing (perception/understanding of others). Both ROI and whole-brain analyses are reported (whole-brain contrasts Mentalizing vs Action with multiple-comparisons correction at p<0.05). The task and regressors explicitly probe social cognition (mentalizing/Theory-of-Mind). No exclusion criteria apply (not limited to ROI-only results; healthy participants reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI studies in healthy adults.

The study reports functional MRI collected while participants performed an explicit social judgement task (approachability from faces), which fits the social-related processing constructs (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy control group of adults (controls reported and analyzed separately) alongside clinical groups. Analyses include whole-brain group × condition contrasts with family-wise error correction and voxel-based (whole-brain) inference in addition to small-volume correction for the amygdala, so results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study uses fMRI while participants performed a social task (ultimatum game), recruiting healthy adult participants (ten males, age 23–28). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (offline whole-brain SVM classification and reporting of discriminating volumes across brain regions) in addition to ROI-based real-time analyses. No participant groups with psychiatric or neurological disorders are the sole focus. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain results reported); no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=60; ages 18–60) that examines neural responses during viewing of human and animal suffering — a social-cognition/empathy task (perception and understanding of others). The paper reports whole-brain random-effects analyses using SPM2 with FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (not limited to ROI-only analyses). Healthy participant results are reported separately and meet the age inclusion (17–65). No exclusion criteria apply (not an ROI-only study, and not restricted to clinical samples). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 18–35) investigating perception of social interactions (viewing dyadic interaction videos) — a social-related task relevant to the review constructs. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (GLM beta maps generated run-wise and whole-brain searchlight analyses) in addition to ROI analyses, so it does not rely solely on ROI results. Healthy participant results are reported separately and meet the age criterion (within 17–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports a functional MRI experiment where healthy late-adolescent participants (N=25; age range 18y1m–22y8m) viewed and judged risk-taking versus safe hand actions—an action observation task tapping social cognition/perception and understanding of others. Participants are healthy undergraduates (no psychiatric/neurological disorders). Whole-brain voxelwise analyses were conducted (SPM8; risk-taking vs. safe contrasts; whole-brain thresholding reported), not ROI-only. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately. Therefore it satisfies: (1) a social-related fMRI task (action observation/social cognition), (2) healthy sample within the 17–65 age criterion, and (3) whole-brain analyses. No exclusion criteria are met (no ROI-only analyses; no clinical-only reporting).

This study reports BOLD fMRI during an explicit social-communication task (irony comprehension), which falls under Social Communication / Perception and Understanding of Others. It includes a healthy control group (n=15) of adults matched to patients; results for controls are reported separately. Imaging analysis used whole-brain random-effects analyses in SPM5 with MNI coordinates and voxelwise thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster extents), and whole-brain between-group contrasts are reported (not ROI-only). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult participants, whole-brain analyses) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates social joint-action (leading, following, mutual) with direct haptic contact—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others and interpersonal interaction. Participants were healthy adults (n=18 after exclusion; mean age 40.4, no neurological/psychiatric history), within the eligible age range. Analyses report whole-brain random-effects results with FDR correction, Talairach coordinates, and cluster thresholds (not limited to ROIs). The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain analyses) and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

The study investigates perception and evaluation of different laughter types—a social communication task tapping perception and understanding of others—using fMRI in healthy adult participants (18 right-handed, mean age 26). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (categorical whole-brain contrasts, second-level random-effects analyses, and whole-brain PPI analyses with cluster-level FWE correction) in addition to ROI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy participant group and are not limited to ROI-only findings. No exclusion criteria apply (participants are healthy adults; whole-brain results are provided). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=20; ages 24–64), meeting the age criterion (17–65). The task is explicitly social/ToM (perception and understanding of others). Whole-brain analyses are reported (ToM > R, ToM > baseline) with voxel- and cluster-level thresholds; although VOI/Bayesian ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain results are provided (not ROI-only). Results for the healthy control group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adult physicians (doctor–patient interaction, empathy/compassion), the reported neuroimaging results are based on an a priori ROI analysis (5 mm spheres around compassion/empathy coordinates) with FWE correction applied within ROIs. The paper does not report whole-brain analyses for the effects of interest. Inclusion criteria require whole-brain analyses (unless both whole-brain and ROI analyses are reported). Because only ROI-based results are presented here, the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although the study tests social/affiliative processing in healthy adult participants (mothers aged 22–45) using fMRI and reports results for healthy controls, the reported analyses use an a priori ROI approach with small-volume correction (SVC) for specified ROIs. The manuscript does not present whole-brain corrected analyses across the entire brain (only ROI/SVC results are described). Per the inclusion criteria, studies must report whole-brain analyses (or both whole-brain and ROI); because this paper reports only ROI-based results, it should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of self- and other-reflection (social-related processing: Perception and Understanding of Self and Others). It includes a healthy control group (n=21) with results reported separately and behavioral/neuroimaging results for HCs are presented. Whole-brain analyses were performed and reported for main task effects in HCs (p<.05 FWE voxel-level); group comparisons also reported (some ROI-restricted tests were used, but whole-brain task effects for healthy participants are available). Participants are adults and no indication they fall outside the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study includes an fMRI task explicitly probing social-related processing (thinking about interpersonal social interactions; measures of self-related social cognition). It reports data from a healthy control group of adults (17 age- and IQ-matched controls; young adults within 17–65) alongside an autism group, with results for controls presented separately. Analyses are not limited to ROIs: whole-brain approaches were used (SPM GLM contrasts across the brain are reported) alongside multivariate/factor-analytic and classification methods that used whole-brain voxel sets. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult participants, whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain, a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Others). It reports data from healthy volunteers and includes a young participant group aged 20–30 (within the 17–65 inclusion window). Whole-brain analyses are reported (pain>no pain and pain>baseline contrasts with FWE-corrected results and whole-brain maps available), alongside ROI analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not limited to ROI-only results and not reporting only clinical groups). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports functional MRI in healthy adult participants performing tasks that probe perception and understanding of others (action observation and weight-discrimination from observed hand actions), which maps onto the review construct ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The paper includes at least one group of healthy participants (n=79 across experiments; n=31 controls in the behavioral/clinical comparison) with results reported separately from the patient group. Analyses used whole-brain preprocessing/normalization and GLMs (MNI normalization, whole-brain maps and whole-brain contrasts are reported, including fusiform activations), not ROI-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only; includes healthy participants’ whole-brain results).

Study acquired task-based BOLD fMRI during an interactive social (mentalizing) Domino game and included a healthy typically-developing (TD) control group (ages 18–34). Results are reported for TD separately alongside ASD and SZ groups. Analysis used whole-brain data-driven ICA (GIG-ICA) and temporal sorting to identify and test default mode network components (not limited to ROIs), with group-level whole-brain component maps and task-related beta-weights reported. Thus the paper meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) includes healthy adults within 17–65 with separate reporting, and (3) whole-brain analyses (ICA). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only or only clinical participants) apply.

This study is an fMRI investigation of social processing (perception of dynamic vs. static facial expressions—‘Perception and Understanding of Others’). It includes a healthy control group (n=13; mean age 24.3) reported separately alongside an ASD group, satisfying the requirement of at least one healthy adult sample within the 17–65 range. Analyses include whole-brain random-effects SPM results with correction for multiple comparisons (as well as ROI/SVC where specified), so it is not ROI-only. The design and reported outcomes directly address social-related neural processing in healthy adults, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This dual‑fMRI hyperscanning study acquired whole‑brain BOLD data in healthy adult participants (38 healthy individuals, mean age 22.4) performing an interactive social task (cooperative, competitive, control pattern game) directly addressing social processing. Analyses used whole‑brain approaches (group ICA and inter‑subject correlation across full brain volumes) and reported interaction‑specific whole‑brain spatial maps and statistics rather than ROI‑only results. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI‑only analyses or clinical‑only samples) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=14; mean age 29.4) who performed a social-related task (categorizing point-light displays as social interaction vs no social interaction), matching the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of others). Data were analyzed with whole-brain random-effects analyses using SPM2, and results are reported as whole-brain corrected statistics (FDR p<0.05), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Participant group is healthy adults within the 17–65 range and results for that group are reported separately. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria (task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses) and does not meet any exclusion criterion.

The study used functional MRI while healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32) read a narrative and rated suspense. The task explicitly evokes and the authors interpret activations in medial frontal cortex and temporo-parietal junction as social-cognitive/theory-of-mind processes (Perception and Understanding of Others). Whole-brain GLM analyses with second-level random-effects and cluster-level FWE correction are reported (in addition to an ROI amygdala analysis), so results are not ROI-only. Participants are within the 17–65 healthy adult range and results for healthy subjects are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact/mutual gaze) in healthy adults (final analyzed sample: 30–32 healthy participants, mean age ~21.7). The task is explicitly social/communication-related (eye contact, shared attention). Analyses include whole-brain voxelwise GLM contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with cluster-level FWE correction, nonparametric permutation validation (SnPM), whole-brain seed-to-voxel gPPI, and voxel-to-voxel interbrain synchronization across the entire brain — i.e., whole-brain results are reported rather than only ROIs. No clinical or patient-only groups are reported; healthy participant results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

Although this fMRI study uses a social-interaction (pseudo-interactive joke) task and reports results for a healthy control group of adults (mean age ~29), the neuroimaging results are reported using a predefined region-of-interest (arMPFC 6-mm sphere) analysis. The authors explicitly state they did not perform whole-brain or functional connectivity analyses due to signal loss around the paranasal sinus/striatum, and no whole-brain results are presented. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain analyses (or both whole-brain and ROI). Because only ROI analyses are reported, the study does not meet the required analysis criterion and should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: healthy adult participants (N=20 analyzed, mean age 20.65, right-handed, within 17–65 range) underwent task-based fMRI. The tasks probe social-related processing (explicit situational inference and future prediction) and stimuli included social situations (41/96 stimuli social), with separate analyses for social vs. non-social trials. Whole-brain analyses were performed using SPM8 with cluster-level correction (p<0.001 height, p<0.05 cluster-corrected) and additional reported contrasts (some results noted at uncorrected thresholds but whole-brain inference was used). Results for healthy participants are reported separately and are the focus. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not limited to clinical groups). Therefore the study should be included.

Participants are adolescents aged 12–18 years (mean ~14–15); the control group comprises typically developing adolescents, not adults. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65 reported separately. Although the task is social (implicit facial emotion processing) and whole-brain analyses (FWE-corrected) were performed, the age criterion is not met (no healthy adult group within 17–65). Therefore the study must be excluded.

This fMRI study used a social-emotional task (viewing empathy-inducing traffic-awareness videos) engaging perception/understanding of others. Sample: 20 healthy adult male participants (age 20–28), reported separately and within the eligible 17–65 range. The authors performed whole-brain random-effects analyses (CV>NV) with results reported at p<0.05 FWE-corrected and presented cluster peaks (bilateral STS), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain results. While ROI analyses were also reported for brain–behavior correlations, whole-brain analyses are present. No clinical/psychiatric-only reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study (Ultimatum Game — a social exchange/cooperation paradigm) conducted in healthy adult volunteers (N=51; group means age 31.1 and 32.2, well within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects GLM analyses (conjunctions, interaction contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction (FDR) and whole-brain PPI connectivity analyses; ROI analyses are also presented but whole-brain results are reported. Results for the healthy participant groups are reported separately. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied (social task during fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=35, mean age 29, within 17–65 range) that investigated processing of facial emotion and identity in a visual short-term memory task. The task probes social-relevant constructs (perception and understanding of others; emotional face processing/social communication). Analyses included whole-brain, random-effects ANCOVA and whole-brain contrasts (FDR-corrected), with reported whole-brain results (emotion and load effects and emotion-by-load contrasts). Results for healthy participants are reported separately and no ROI-only restriction applies. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related whole-brain fMRI study in healthy adults (n=12, mean age 25.2) using Heider–Simmel-style animations to probe agency attribution and theory-of-mind/intentionality (social cognition). Analysis used whole-brain random-effects SPM2 contrasts (reported at p<0.001 uncorrected) with activation maps across cortex (STS, IFG, temporal pole, occipital areas), not limited to ROIs. Participants were healthy and within the 17–65 age range. No clinical-group–only results or ROI-only reporting were found. Therefore all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses) are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study examines social-related processing (observation of social touch) in adult participants and includes a healthy neurotypical (NT) group (n=21) with results reported separately. Participants are adult men (within 17–65). The study used functional MRI during a social task (observing social vs. non-social touch) and reports whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM with MNI peak coordinates referenced in Supplementary Tables/Figures) as well as ROI-based MVPA; inclusion allows studies reporting both whole-brain and ROI results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages ~26) performing a body-perception task that probes self- and other-related processing (ratings of “To what degree is this picture you?”), which falls under the social-related constructs (Perception and Understanding of Self and Others). Results are reported from whole-brain analyses (FEAT/FLAME, cluster-corrected maps reported; whole-brain contrasts and parametric analyses described). At least one group of healthy participants is reported separately and no ROI-only restriction applies. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study (3T) of prosody perception and production, which falls under Social Communication (a social-related construct). Participants were healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58). The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects analyses (thresholded at p<0.05 FDR, k>5) and presents whole-brain results (in addition to SVC), not ROI-only analyses. Behavioral and fMRI correlations with empathy (IRI and PPI-R) are reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (no patient-only sample, and whole-brain outcomes are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (male, 18–24) who performed an aesthetic judgment (beauty ratings) while listening to popular and artistic music. The authors report whole-brain voxel-wise contrasts and one-way ANOVA with cluster-level FDR correction (in addition to ROI analyses), satisfying the whole-brain analysis requirement. Although the task was an aesthetic judgment rather than an explicit social task, the study specifically investigates and reports engagement of default mode/ToM and cognitive empathy regions (arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ/temporal pole, hippocampus) and interprets these as social-cognitive/mentalizing processes (Perception and Understanding of Others). Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. Note: task is indirect social processing (inferred mentalizing), but authors’ analyses and interpretations align with inclusion constructs.

fMRI study using a social-related task (Face Matching Task assessing perception of others’ emotional faces, fear vs neutral). Participants: a healthy adult sample (N=10; mean age 25, within 17–65). Whole-brain analyses reported: second-level whole-brain GLM (one-sample t-tests) and ICA-derived spatial maps tested across the brain (FDR-corrected), not limited to ROI analyses. Results for healthy participants are reported separately (only healthy group). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task is social-related (facial emotion discrimination—perception and understanding of others/social communication). 2) Healthy adult participants reported separately: both groups (excessive smartphone users screened to exclude current psychiatric diagnoses, and normal controls) are adults aged 19–35. 3) Whole-brain analyses are reported (group differences with FWE-corrected, cluster-level results reported across the whole brain), not only ROI analyses (ROIs are secondary). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore study is appropriate for inclusion in the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=31, mean age 24.3) that probes social cognition: formation of trustworthiness impressions from advisers (honesty/dishonesty), advice-taking, and subsequent trust decisions in a trust game — clearly social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, social communication). The manuscript reports whole-brain analyses: multivariate voxel-wise searchlight MVPA (whole-brain gray matter mask) and whole-brain univariate GLM results corrected for multiple comparisons (voxel-level p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05). Although an OFC ROI was used for a post-hoc test, whole-brain results are primary and reported. Participants are healthy adults and results pertain to them. Hence all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study is an fMRI investigation of theory-of-mind in healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65) and thus addresses the review topic. However, the report centers on ROI-based multivoxel pattern analyses (individually-defined ToM ROIs and language control ROIs) and does not present whole-brain voxelwise results or a whole-brain analysis for the primary experimental contrasts. The inclusion criteria require that whole-brain analyses be reported (or both whole-brain and ROI analyses). Because the published results appear to rely exclusively on ROI analyses (MVPA within predefined ROIs) with no whole-brain statistical maps/results provided for the main contrasts, the study fails the requirement for whole-brain analyses and must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in adults (controls: mean age ~32, range 20–46) performing an emotional prosody task, which is a social-communication/perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Healthy control results are reported separately and whole-brain mixed-effects analyses were performed (FSL/FLAME) with cluster FWE correction; ROI analyses were also performed but whole-brain results are available. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group reported separately, whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria are met.

This study used fMRI while participants performed social-related tasks (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces). It reports data from healthy adult participants (n=47; ages within 17–65) and presents whole-brain second-level random-effects analyses for the social versus gender contrasts (with cluster-level correction reported), satisfying the whole-brain requirement. Although an additional ASD group was included, healthy participants’ results are reported separately. The paper also includes some ROI analyses for a targeted ASD vs control comparison, but these are supplemental and do not preclude inclusion because whole-brain results are available. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used fMRI in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) while they observed and executed others’ hand actions—an explicit social-related task falling under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’/action understanding. The methods report both ROI and whole-brain analyses (a whole-brain analysis at p<0.001 uncorrected is described), so it is not ROI-only. All participants are healthy adults (17–65 criterion met), and results are reported for this healthy group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only samples or ROI-only reporting) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge — Perception and Understanding of Others) in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24.6). The task involved an explicit social-related paradigm (bodies vs names paired with trait-based or neutral statements) during MRI. Analyses include whole-brain univariate GLM results and whole-brain psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analyses with voxel-level thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; results are not limited to ROI-only reporting. Healthy participants’ results are reported separately and no clinical groups dominate the sample. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports fMRI data collected while participants performed a social-referential task (Visual–Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task) directly probing Perception/Understanding of Self and Others, meeting the review’s domain. The sample comprises 20 healthy adult women (ages 18–52), within the 17–65 range, with results reported for the healthy group. Analyses include whole-brain random-effects SPM8 results (GLM contrasts reported across the whole brain) alongside ROI/SVC follow-ups; whole-brain findings are presented (voxel-wise thresholds and cluster reporting), not ROI-only. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of self-referential social processing (conceptual and agentic self/other recollection) in healthy adults (18 participants, ages 19–29). The fMRI data were acquired during task performance (scanned test phases), and the paper reports whole-brain analyses (whole-brain FWE-corrected results and contrasts) in addition to ROI analyses. All inclusion criteria are met: (1) social-related task targeting Perception/Understanding of Self; (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65; (3) whole-brain analyses reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; no clinical-only sample). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This fMRI study examines perception of social cues (fearful facial expressions with gaze direction) — a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy control group of adults (mean age 23.7, within 17–65) with whole-brain voxel-wise analyses reported (subject- and group-level GLMs, mixed-effects FLAME, permutation testing, FWE-corrected maps). Although an ASD group is also studied, results for healthy controls are reported separately. Both whole-brain and ROI analyses are presented, so it does not meet any exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attentional orienting to social gaze vs arrow cues; cross-modal social voice target), conducted in healthy adults (n=22, mean age 22.95). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (with FWE correction) as well as ROI/small-volume analyses; it is not ROI-only. Results for the healthy participant group are clearly reported. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used functional MRI while participants completed an altruism task probing social decision-making (focus on partner, ethics) and reports neural encoding of social attributes (others’ payoffs, fairness, TPJ, precuneus). Participants were healthy adults (N=55 altruism; subset N=37 also did food task), ages within the 17–65 range. Analyses include whole-brain multivariate searchlight decoding and group-level random-effects tests (FWE cluster correction), not limited to ROI-only results (ROI post-hoc tests are supplemental). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task addressing perception/understanding of others and social decision-making; (2) healthy adult sample reported separately; (3) whole-brain analyses are reported. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (final N=23, mean age 26.4) performing a social perception task (observing agents interacting; manipulations probe perception/understanding of others, person perception, action observation and mentalizing). Neuroimaging analyses were conducted and reported at the whole-brain level (voxel-wise threshold, cluster reporting; not ROI-only). Participants were healthy young adults (within 17–65) and results for this group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are met (not clinical-only; whole-brain results presented). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social gaze processing (social perception/understanding of others) while participants performed a social-related task (responding to virtual characters’ gaze shifts). Sample: healthy adults (n=30 after exclusions), age range 19–41, meeting the required age group. The authors report whole-brain analyses (GLM second-level flexible factorial with cluster-forming p<0.001 and FWE cluster correction p<0.05) for main effects and interactions. They also conducted a psychophysiological interaction analysis (gPPI) with FWE voxel-level correction; although a seed was used, whole-brain/main effects are reported and ROI-only reporting is not the sole analytic approach. No results are reported exclusively for clinical groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in which participants listened to 90-s connected prosodic speech (affective/communicative prosody), which pertains to social communication and perception of others. It includes a healthy control group of adults (8 males, mean age ~23) within the 17–65 range and reports whole-brain analyses (one-sample and two-sample t-tests, conjunction analyses, FDR-corrected results). Although a clinical HFA group is also included, results for healthy participants are reported separately. Both whole-brain and ROI analyses are present, and whole-brain results are provided, so the study does not meet any exclusion criteria. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study uses task-based fMRI (empathy-for-pain) addressing social processing (empathy/perception of others’ pain). It includes a healthy control group of adults (ages 19–63) with results reported separately (group-specific correlations in anterior insula). Although a priori ROI analyses were performed, the authors also report whole-brain analyses (Supplementary Table 1 and whole-brain contrasts with reported coordinates) and group comparisons outside the ROI. Thus all inclusion criteria are met: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult participants within 17–65, and whole-brain results are presented (in addition to ROI analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used fMRI during social-cognitive tasks: action observation and action understanding (theory-of-mind related), which fall under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The sample included a healthy control group (reported separately; Experiment 1: n=16 HCs in analyses; Experiment 2: n=16 HCs) even though patients with ALS were also studied. Whole-brain second-level random-effects analyses were conducted and reported (e.g., understand>observe, HC>ALS contrasts) alongside some ROI SVCs; thus whole-brain results are available. Behavioral ToM measures (RME) accompany the imaging. Minor caveat: explicit participant age range (17–65) is not listed in the full text, but participants were adult controls matched for age and gender; given typical adult recruitment and matching, inclusion is judged appropriate.

The study used functional MRI (dyadic fMRI) during an explicit social task (face-to-face eye contact), recruiting healthy adult participants (38 individuals; ages 18–33 with mean 22). Whole-brain preprocessing and group-level whole-brain analyses are reported (GLM, paired t-tests, cluster results with MNI coordinates and atlas labeling), and ICA on whole-brain dyadic data. Results are not limited to ROI analyses and healthy participant results are reported separately. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used fMRI during a social-related task (self- and other-reflection vs. facts), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Self and Others. It reports data from a healthy control group (n=33; adults matched 18–65) with results for controls presented separately alongside a patient group. Analyses were whole-brain (FEAT/FSL mixed-effects GLM with cluster-level correction, Z=2.3, p<0.05), not ROI-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult participants with separate results, whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (women aged 18–35) who performed a self-related task (rating whether odors/peptide-supplemented body odors were ones they would like to smell like), which falls under the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Self'. The paper explicitly states that whole-brain analysis was performed (in addition to small-volume ROI analyses) and reports activation coordinates in MNI space. Results for healthy participants are reported separately and there are no clinical groups only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=31, ages 18–35) that measured whole-brain BOLD responses while participants performed a gender-judgement cover task viewing faces with/without facial disfigurement. Stimuli and contrasts target social perception and processing of others (stigmatization, empathy, social cognition), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The study reports whole-brain group analyses (SnPM, cluster-level FWE correction) and also an item-wise ROI control analysis; results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not limited to clinical groups). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports fMRI data collected from a group of healthy adult participants (10 right-handed males, ages 24–37) performing a social-related task: perception/integration of non-verbal vocalizations with facial movements (social communication/perception of others). Group-level voxelwise whole-volume analyses (voxel-by-voxel parametric t tests with multiple comparisons correction using AlphaSim) are reported alongside ROI analyses, so findings are not limited to ROI-only results. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately. Although slice coverage was limited (targeting lateral temporal cortex), analyses were voxelwise rather than ROI-only. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (29 scanned, 27 analyzed; mean age 25.6) using a social task (delegated inter-temporal choice; learning/simulating another person’s preferences—perception and understanding of others). Imaging analyses used whole-brain random-effects GLMs with cluster-defining thresholds and FWE correction (whole-brain results reported), not restricted to ROI-only findings. Healthy participant results are reported separately and meet the age range criterion. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this fMRI study tested social tasks (theory-of-mind and social attribution) in healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65), the primary task-activation analyses were performed using localized ICA restricted to a temporoparietal ROI. The identification of task-related components and the main activation results are ROI-based rather than derived from whole-brain task GLM/contrast maps. While the paper reports whole-brain seed-to-voxel connectivity maps, the core task activation results required for inclusion in the meta-analysis are not whole-brain analyses. Hence it fails the requirement that task results be whole-brain (or include whole-brain task contrasts). Therefore the study should be excluded.

This study used functional MRI while participants performed social decision-making tasks (cooperation and competition), addressing social processing (perception/understanding of self and others). Participants were healthy adults (final N=24; ages 19–31), satisfying the age and health criteria. The paper reports whole-brain analyses to identify regions (pgACC, area 9) and additionally presents ROI follow-ups; because whole-brain results are reported, the study meets the whole-brain requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not restricted to clinical groups; not ROI-only). Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30, ages 19–39) that probes social cognition (kinship effects, moral dilemmas, perspective taking — constructs within perception/understanding of others and affiliation/attachment). The study reports whole-brain inter-subject correlation (ISC) analyses across the entire brain and a whole-brain GLM for the moral-decision task (with multiple comparison correction), not ROI-only results. No clinical or patient-only groups are reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses) and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study examines social-related processing (personal familiarity of close others and one’s home) and reports whole-brain analyses with a healthy control group reported separately, the healthy participants are described as ‘healthy elderly’ / older adults (study of aMCI and age-matched elderly controls). The review’s inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. The healthy sample in this paper falls outside that age range, so the study does not meet the age criterion. Therefore it must be excluded. All other inclusion/exclusion criteria (task is social-related; whole-brain analyses; healthy group reported) are satisfied, but failing the age requirement leads to exclusion.

Study reports whole-brain fMRI analyses (SPM8; one-sample t-tests with cluster-wise correction) in a sample of healthy adults (n=19, age 18–51). The task explicitly probes emotional prosody comprehension including complex social emotions (pride, guilt) and the paper frames these as requiring theory-of-mind/social cognitive processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Results for healthy participants are reported separately and analyses are whole-brain (not ROI-only). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (anticipation of touching an animate human vs an inanimate mannequin), involving social processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (n=32, ages 21–33; task fMRI completed by 21), so healthy group results are reported separately. Crucially, the authors present whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (paired-sample t-tests, FDR-corrected maps) and whole-brain covariate analyses with narcissism scores; ROI analyses are supplemental. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not clinical-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 22.8) performing a social-perception task (judging facing-towards vs away in point-light and human-like walkers), which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Whole-brain second-level contrasts were obtained and reported; although subsequent analyses used masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing systems, the paper includes whole-brain analysis (and reports cluster/peak coordinates), so it is not limited to ROI-only results. Healthy participant results are reported separately and no clinical-only samples are used. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (age ~22) and uses a social-related task (trait evaluations of in-group/out-group politicians), the reported neuroimaging results are based on small-volume/ROI analyses (bilateral vACC ROI with small-volume correction). The manuscript does not report whole-brain analysis results—findings are presented from the predefined vACC ROI only. Per inclusion criteria requiring whole-brain analyses (or both whole-brain and ROI), this study must be excluded.

This study reports fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants (male, 18–40) completed an empathy-for-pain paradigm — a social cognition task probing perception and understanding of others. Participants are healthy and results for them are reported separately. The paper includes whole-brain analyses (FWE-corrected) as well as ROI analyses; therefore it is not limited to ROI-only reporting. No results are reported exclusively from clinical groups and no exclusion criteria apply. The methods and results clearly address social-related processing and satisfy all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is a functional MRI study in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29) using an explicit social judgment task (evaluations of target persons across situations). The task probes social processing (perception/understanding of others; social evaluation). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (multilevel whole-brain MLM; voxelwise results reported at P<0.001 and supplementary material) in addition to ROI follow-ups. Participants are healthy and results for this group are reported separately. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during a social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain analyses reported) and none of the exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI whole-brain study of social evaluation (Social Feedback Task) in a sample of healthy adolescents/young adults (N=56; age range 17–20). The task probes social-related processes (social inclusion/exclusion, social evaluation), and analyses report whole-brain results using conservative FWE correction (not ROI-only). Participants were screened to exclude current Axis I disorders and results for the healthy group are reported separately. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults (ages 17–65).

Study reports BOLD fMRI data from healthy adult participants (n=14, ages 23–50) performing a task contrasting social vs. non-social stimuli (IAPS images). Although the in-scanner task was a valence appraisal, socialness was explicitly manipulated and contrasted, addressing social-related processing. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (social > nonsocial contrast with FDR correction) as well as ROI analyses. Participants were healthy and results for them are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

Participants: healthy adults (mean age ~22); task: fMRI during viewing of dynamic facial expressions (social perception) — meets review topic and participant criteria. However, the reported analyses focus on a priori ROI/small-volume-corrected results (amygdala, insula, striatum, OFC) with statistics presented from ROI/SVC. The manuscript does not report whole-brain (whole-brain corrected or unthresholded whole-brain) results independent of ROI/SVC; all primary significant findings described are ROI-based. The review’s inclusion requirement mandates whole-brain analyses (or both whole-brain and ROI). Because only ROI/SVC analyses are reported in the provided full text, the study fails the analytic inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI during social-related processing (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective theory-of-mind) in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=74). Results for healthy participants are reported separately. The authors conducted and report whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-tests, within-subject ANOVA, whole-brain threshold p<0.05 FWE-corrected, k=10) as well as ROI analyses; the presence of whole-brain results satisfies the inclusion criterion that whole-brain analyses be reported. No exclusion criteria are met (it is not limited to ROI-only analyses, and it does not report only clinical groups). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: participants viewed realistic two-person aggressive interactions while attentional focus (on aggressor vs victim) was manipulated, addressing perception/understanding of others. Sample consists of healthy adults (N=15 males, mean age 23.6), within the 17–65 range, with results reported for healthy participants. Analyses include whole-brain GLM results (cluster-size correction, Talairach space) and whole-brain connectivity maps; not limited to ROI-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/mentalising) using the Empathic Accuracy Task with naturalistic videos. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final fMRI sample n=34, age 20–30) with results reported for the healthy group.
